questions.questionText:
Statement: All roses are flowers.

Conclusions:
I. Some flowers are roses.
II. All flowers are roses.

Which conclusion(s) follow?
questions.explanation: From 'All roses are flowers': Conclusion I 'Some flowers are roses' follows because those roses are also flowers. Conclusion II 'All flowers are roses' does not follow because there can be other flowers. Answer: Only I.

questions.questionText:
Statement: No cat is a dog.

Conclusions:
I. No dog is a cat.
II. Some cats are dogs.

Which conclusion(s) follow?
questions.explanation: From 'No cat is a dog': Conclusion I 'No dog is a cat' follows (conversion of negative universal). Conclusion II 'Some cats are dogs' contradicts the statement. Answer: Only I.

questions.questionText:
Statement: Some students are athletes.

Conclusions:
I. Some athletes are students.
II. All students are athletes.

Which conclusion(s) follow?
questions.explanation: From 'Some students are athletes': Conclusion I 'Some athletes are students' follows (conversion of particular statement). Conclusion II 'All students are athletes' does not follow ('some' ≠ 'all'). Answer: Only I.

questions.questionText:
Statements:
1. All doctors are professionals.
2. All professionals are educated.

Conclusions:
I. All doctors are educated.
II. Some educated people are doctors.

Which conclusion(s) follow?
questions.explanation: Chain: All doctors→professionals→educated, so 'All doctors are educated' follows (I). Since all doctors are educated, some educated people are doctors (II). Answer: Both I and II.

questions.questionText:
Statement: All mangoes are fruits.

Conclusions:
I. Some mangoes are not fruits.
II. Some fruits are mangoes.

Which conclusion(s) follow?
questions.explanation: From 'All mangoes are fruits': Conclusion I 'Some mangoes are not fruits' contradicts the statement. Conclusion II 'Some fruits are mangoes' follows. Answer: Only II.

questions.questionText:
Statements:
1. No bird is a mammal.
2. All bats are mammals.

Conclusions:
I. No bat is a bird.
II. Some bats are birds.

Which conclusion(s) follow?
questions.explanation: From 'No bird is a mammal' and 'All bats are mammals': Since bats are mammals and no bird is a mammal, no bat can be a bird (I follows). Conclusion II contradicts this. Answer: Only I.

questions.questionText:
Statement: Some books are interesting.

Conclusions:
I. Some interesting things are books.
II. No book is interesting.

Which conclusion(s) follow?
questions.explanation: From 'Some books are interesting': Conclusion I follows (conversion). Conclusion II contradicts the statement. Answer: Only I.

questions.questionText:
Statements:
1. Some flowers are roses.
2. All roses are plants.

Conclusions:
I. Some flowers are plants.
II. All flowers are plants.

Which conclusion(s) follow?
questions.explanation: Chain: Some flowers are roses, and all roses are plants, so some flowers are plants (I follows). But not all flowers need to be plants (II doesn't follow). Answer: Only I.

questions.questionText:
Statement: No metal is a liquid.

Conclusions:
I. Some metals are not liquids.
II. Some liquids are not metals.

Which conclusion(s) follow?
questions.explanation: From 'No metal is a liquid': All metals are not liquids, so 'Some metals are not liquids' follows (I). Similarly, 'Some liquids are not metals' follows (II). Answer: Both I and II.

questions.questionText:
Statements:
1. All cats are mammals.
2. All mammals are animals.
3. All animals are living things.

Conclusion: All cats are living things.

Does this conclusion follow?
questions.explanation: Chain: All cats→mammals→animals→living things. Therefore, all cats are living things. Answer: Yes.

questions.questionText:
Statement: All squares are rectangles.

Conclusions:
I. All rectangles are squares.
II. Some rectangles are squares.

Which conclusion(s) follow?
questions.explanation: From 'All squares are rectangles': Conclusion I 'All rectangles are squares' does not follow (reverse doesn't work). Conclusion II 'Some rectangles are squares' follows (those squares are rectangles). Answer: Only II.

questions.questionText:
Statements:
1. Some politicians are honest.
2. All honest people are trustworthy.

Conclusions:
I. Some politicians are trustworthy.
II. All politicians are honest.

Which conclusion(s) follow?
questions.explanation: Chain: Some politicians are honest, and all honest are trustworthy, so some politicians are trustworthy (I follows). Conclusion II 'All politicians are honest' does not follow from 'some'. Answer: Only I.

questions.questionText:
Statement: Some teachers are strict.

Conclusions:
I. Some teachers are not strict.
II. All teachers are strict.

Which conclusion(s) follow?
questions.explanation: From 'Some teachers are strict': We cannot conclude 'Some teachers are not strict' (could be all are strict). We also cannot conclude 'All teachers are strict'. Neither follows definitively. Answer: Neither I nor II.

questions.questionText:
Statements:
1. No pen is a pencil.
2. Some pencils are erasers.

Conclusions:
I. Some erasers are not pens.
II. No eraser is a pen.

Which conclusion(s) follow?
questions.explanation: Some pencils are erasers, and no pen is a pencil, so those erasers (which are pencils) cannot be pens. Thus 'Some erasers are not pens' follows (I). But we cannot say 'No eraser is a pen' because other erasers might be pens (II doesn't follow). Answer: Only I.

questions.questionText:
Statements:
1. All books are papers.
2. All papers are notes.

Conclusions:
I. All books are notes.
II. Some notes are books.

Which conclusion(s) follow?
questions.explanation: Chain: All books→papers→notes, so 'All books are notes' follows (I). Since all books are notes, 'Some notes are books' also follows (II). Answer: Both I and II.

questions.questionText:
Statement: All lions are carnivores.

Conclusions:
I. Some carnivores are lions.
II. Some lions are not carnivores.

Which conclusion(s) follow?
questions.explanation: From 'All lions are carnivores': Conclusion I 'Some carnivores are lions' follows. Conclusion II 'Some lions are not carnivores' contradicts the statement (all lions are carnivores). Answer: Only I.

questions.questionText:
Statements:
1. Some students are athletes.
2. Some athletes are musicians.

Conclusion: Some students are musicians.

Does this conclusion follow?
questions.explanation: Some-Some chain is invalid. The student-athletes might be different from the athlete-musicians. We cannot conclude that some students are musicians. Answer: No.

questions.questionText:
Statement: No student is lazy.

Conclusions:
I. All students are hard-working.
II. Some students are not lazy.

Which conclusion(s) follow?
questions.explanation: From 'No student is lazy': Conclusion I 'All students are hard-working' does not follow (not lazy ≠ hard-working; could be average). Conclusion II 'Some students are not lazy' follows (all are not lazy, so definitely some are not). Answer: Only II.
